\chapter{Table of Contents}
\label{index:table-of-contents}\label{index:welcome-to-pytan-s-documentation}

\section{Description}
\label{description::doc}\label{description:description}
This is a set of packages and scripts that provides a simple way for programmatically interfacing with Tanium's SOAP API. It is comprised of four parts:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Tanium Server SOAP API: The SOAP server embedded into the Tanium server itself, listens on port 444 but is also available via port 443.

\item {} 
TaniumPy Python Package ({\hyperref[taniumpy:module-taniumpy]{\code{taniumpy}}}): A python package comprised of a set of python objects automatically generated from the WSDL file that describe the Tanium SOAP API. These python objects handle the serialization and deserialization of XML to and from the Tanium Server SOAP API. Located in \code{lib/taniumpy}

\item {} 
PyTan Python Package: ({\hyperref[pytan:module-pytan]{\code{pytan}}}): A python package that provides a set of methods to make interfacing with TaniumPy more human friendly. Located in \code{lib/pytan}

\item {} 
PyTan Command Line Scripts: A set of command line scripts that utilize the PyTan Package ({\hyperref[pytan:module-pytan]{\code{pytan}}}) to make it easy for non-programmers to create/get/delete/ask/deploy objects via the Tanium Server SOAP API.

\end{itemize}


\section{Why it was created}
\label{description:why-it-was-created}
This was created to solve for the following needs:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Create a python module ({\hyperref[taniumpy:module-taniumpy]{\code{taniumpy}}}) to provide a set of methods for making it easier to programmatically interface with Tanium via the SOAP API.

\item {} 
Create a set of command line scripts utilizing the {\hyperref[taniumpy:module-taniumpy]{\code{taniumpy}}} module that handle the argument parsing, thereby providing non-programmers with command line access to the functionality therein.

\item {} 
Provide a way to ask questions and get results via Python and/or the command line.

\item {} 
Provide a way to deploy actions and get results via Python and/or the command line.

\item {} 
Provide a way to export/import objects in JSON via Python and/or the command line.

\end{itemize}


\section{Requirements}
\label{description:requirements}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Python 2.7

\item {} 
A working install of Tanium Server 6.2

\end{itemize}


\section{Installation}
\label{description:installation}\begin{description}
\item[{Windows Installation}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Download Python 2.7 from \href{https://www.python.org/downloads/windows/}{https://www.python.org/downloads/windows/}

\item {} 
Install Python 2.7 -- if you accept the default paths it will install to \code{C:\textbackslash{}Python27}

\item {} 
Copy PyTan from github to your local machine somewhere

\item {} 
If you did not accept the default install path for Python 2.7, edit \code{pytan\textbackslash{}winbin\textbackslash{}CONFIG.bat} to change the \emph{PYTHON} variable to point to the full path of \emph{python.exe}

\end{itemize}

\item[{OS X Installation}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
OS X 10.8 and higher come with Python 2.7 out of the box

\item {} 
Copy PyTan from github to your local machine somewhere

\end{itemize}

\item[{Linux Installation}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Ensure Python 2.7 is installed

\item {} 
Ensure the first \emph{python} binary in your path points to your Python 2.7 installation

\item {} 
Copy PyTan from github to your local machine somewhere

\end{itemize}

\end{description}

Creates a connection to a Tanium SOAP Server on host:port

\paragraph{Notes}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
port 444 is the default SOAP port

\item {} 
port 443 forwards /soap/ URLs to the SOAP port

\item {} 
Use port 444 if you have direct access to it

\end{itemize}

\subparagraph{Asking a Manual Question}
\label{pytan.handler:asking-a-manual-question}\index{ask\_manual() (pytan.handler.Handler method)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{pytan.handler:pytan.handler.Handler.ask_manual}\pysiglinewithargsret{\code{Handler.}\bfcode{ask\_manual}}{\emph{get\_results=True}, \emph{**kwargs}}{}
Ask a manual question using definitions and get the results back

This method requires in-depth knowledge of how filters and options are created in the API,
and as such is not meant for human consumption. Use {\hyperref[pytan.handler:pytan.handler.Handler.ask_manual_human]{\code{ask\_manual\_human()}}} instead.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode
\textbf{sensor\_defs} : str, dict, list of str or dict
\begin{quote}

sensor definitions
\end{quote}

\textbf{question\_filter\_defs} : dict, list of dict, optional
\begin{quote}

question filter definitions
\end{quote}

\textbf{question\_option\_defs} : dict, list of dict, optional
\begin{quote}

question option definitions
\end{quote}

\textbf{get\_results} : bool, optional
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
True: wait for result completion after asking question

\item {} 
False: just ask the question and return it in \emph{ret}

\end{itemize}

\item[{Returns}] \leavevmode
\textbf{ret} : dict, containing:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\emph{question\_object} : {\hyperref[taniumpy.object_types:taniumpy.object_types.question.Question]{\code{taniumpy.object\_types.question.Question}}}

\item {} 
\emph{question\_results} : {\hyperref[taniumpy.object_types:taniumpy.object_types.result_set.ResultSet]{\code{taniumpy.object\_types.result\_set.ResultSet}}}

\end{itemize}

\end{description}\end{quote}


\strong{See also:}

\begin{description}
\item[{{\hyperref[pytan.constants:pytan.constants.FILTER_MAPS]{\code{pytan.constants.FILTER\_MAPS}}}}] \leavevmode
valid filter dictionaries for filters

\item[{{\hyperref[pytan.constants:pytan.constants.OPTION_MAPS]{\code{pytan.constants.OPTION\_MAPS}}}}] \leavevmode

\end{description}

\index{ask\_manual\_human() (pytan.handler.Handler method)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{pytan.handler:pytan.handler.Handler.ask_manual_human}\pysiglinewithargsret{\code{Handler.}\bfcode{ask\_manual\_human}}{\emph{**kwargs}}{}
Ask a manual question using human strings and get the results back

This method takes a string or list of strings and parses them into
their corresponding definitions needed by {\hyperref[pytan.handler:pytan.handler.Handler.ask_manual]{\code{ask\_manual()}}}
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode
\textbf{sensors} : str, list of str
\begin{quote}

sensors (columns) to include in question
\end{quote}

\textbf{question\_filters} : str, list of str, optional
\begin{quote}

filters that apply to the whole question
\end{quote}

\textbf{question\_options} : str, list of str, optional
\begin{quote}

options that apply to the whole question
\end{quote}

\textbf{get\_results} : bool, optional
\begin{quote}

True: wait for result completion after asking question
False: just ask the question and return it in result
\end{quote}

\item[{Returns}] \leavevmode
\textbf{result} : dict, containing:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\emph{question\_object} : {\hyperref[taniumpy.object_types:taniumpy.object_types.question.Question]{\code{taniumpy.object\_types.question.Question}}}

\item {} 
\emph{question\_results} : {\hyperref[taniumpy.object_types:taniumpy.object_types.result_set.ResultSet]{\code{taniumpy.object\_types.result\_set.ResultSet}}}

\end{itemize}

\end{description}\end{quote}

\subparagraph{Deploy an Action}
\label{pytan.handler:deploy-an-action}\index{deploy\_action() (pytan.handler.Handler method)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{pytan.handler:pytan.handler.Handler.deploy_action}\pysiglinewithargsret{\code{Handler.}\bfcode{deploy\_action}}{\emph{run=False}, \emph{get\_results=True}, \emph{**kwargs}}{}
Deploy an action and get the results back

This method requires in-depth knowledge of how filters and options are created in the API, and as such is not meant for human consumption. Use {\hyperref[pytan.handler:pytan.handler.Handler.deploy_action_human]{\code{deploy\_action\_human()}}} instead.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode
\textbf{package\_def} : dict
\begin{quote}

definition that describes a package
\end{quote}

\textbf{action\_filter\_defs} : str, dict, list of str or dict, optional
\begin{quote}

action filter definitions
\end{quote}

\textbf{action\_option\_defs} : dict, list of dict, optional
\begin{quote}

action filter option definitions
\end{quote}

\textbf{start\_seconds\_from\_now} : int, optional
\begin{quote}

start action N seconds from now
\end{quote}

\textbf{expire\_seconds} : int, optional
\begin{quote}

expire action N seconds from now, will be derived from package if not supplied
\end{quote}

\textbf{run} : bool, optional
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
False: just ask the question that pertains to verify action, export the results to CSV, and raise RunFalse -- does not deploy the action

\item {} 
True: actually deploy the action

\end{itemize}

\textbf{get\_results} : bool, optional
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
True: wait for result completion after deploying action

\item {} 
False: just deploy the action and return the object in \emph{ret}

\end{itemize}

\item[{Returns}] \leavevmode
\textbf{ret} : dict, containing:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\emph{action\_object} : {\hyperref[taniumpy.object_types:taniumpy.object_types.action.Action]{\code{taniumpy.object\_types.action.Action}}}

\item {} 
\emph{action\_results} : {\hyperref[taniumpy.object_types:taniumpy.object_types.result_set.ResultSet]{\code{taniumpy.object\_types.result\_set.ResultSet}}}

\item {} 
\emph{action\_progress\_human} : str, progress map in human form

\item {} 
\emph{action\_progress\_map} : dict, progress map in dictionary form

\item {} 
\emph{pre\_action\_question\_results} : {\hyperref[taniumpy.object_types:taniumpy.object_types.result_set.ResultSet]{\code{taniumpy.object\_types.result\_set.ResultSet}}}

\end{itemize}

\end{description}\end{quote}


\strong{See also:}

\begin{description}
\item[{{\hyperref[pytan.constants:pytan.constants.FILTER_MAPS]{\code{pytan.constants.FILTER\_MAPS}}}}] \leavevmode
valid filter dictionaries for filters

\item[{{\hyperref[pytan.constants:pytan.constants.OPTION_MAPS]{\code{pytan.constants.OPTION\_MAPS}}}}] \leavevmode
valid option dictionaries for options

\end{description}


\paragraph{Examples}

\end{Verbatim}

\index{deploy\_action\_human() (pytan.handler.Handler method)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{pytan.handler:pytan.handler.Handler.deploy_action_human}\pysiglinewithargsret{\code{Handler.}\bfcode{deploy\_action\_human}}{\emph{**kwargs}}{}
Deploy an action and get the results back

This method takes a string or list of strings and parses them into
their corresponding definitions needed by {\hyperref[pytan.handler:pytan.handler.Handler.deploy_action]{\code{deploy\_action()}}}
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode
\textbf{package} : str
\begin{quote}

each string must describe a package
\end{quote}

\textbf{action\_filters} : str, list of str, optional
\begin{quote}

each string must describe a sensor and a filter which limits which computers the action will deploy \emph{package} to
\end{quote}

\textbf{action\_options} : str, list of str, optional
\begin{quote}

options to apply to \emph{action\_filters}
\end{quote}

\textbf{start\_seconds\_from\_now} : int, optional
\begin{quote}

start action N seconds from now
\end{quote}

\textbf{expire\_seconds} : int, optional
\begin{quote}

expire action N seconds from now, will be derived from package if not supplied
\end{quote}

\textbf{run} : bool, optional
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
False: just ask the question that pertains to verify action, export the results to CSV, and raise RunFalse -- does not deploy the action

\item {} 
True: actually deploy the action

\end{itemize}

\textbf{get\_results} : bool, optional
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
True: wait for result completion after deploying action

\item {} 
False: just deploy the action and return the object in \emph{ret}

\end{itemize}

\item[{Returns}] \leavevmode
\textbf{ret} : dict, containing:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\emph{action\_object} : {\hyperref[taniumpy.object_types:taniumpy.object_types.action.Action]{\code{taniumpy.object\_types.action.Action}}}

\item {} 
\emph{action\_results} : {\hyperref[taniumpy.object_types:taniumpy.object_types.result_set.ResultSet]{\code{taniumpy.object\_types.result\_set.ResultSet}}}

\item {} 
\emph{action\_progress\_human} : str, progress map in human form

\item {} 
\emph{action\_progress\_map} : dict, progress map in dictionary form

\item {} 
\emph{pre\_action\_question\_results} : {\hyperref[taniumpy.object_types:taniumpy.object_types.result_set.ResultSet]{\code{taniumpy.object\_types.result\_set.ResultSet}}}

\end{itemize}

\end{description}\end{quote}


\strong{See also:}

\begin{description}
\item[{{\hyperref[pytan.constants:pytan.constants.FILTER_MAPS]{\code{pytan.constants.FILTER\_MAPS}}}}] \leavevmode
valid filter dictionaries for filters

\item[{{\hyperref[pytan.constants:pytan.constants.OPTION_MAPS]{\code{pytan.constants.OPTION\_MAPS}}}}] \leavevmode
valid option dictionaries for options

\end{description}

\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{action\PYGZus{}options} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s}{max\PYGZus{}data\PYGZus{}age:3600}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s}{and}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{]}
\end{Verbatim}

\end{fulllineitems}

\subparagraph{Export Object}
\label{pytan.handler:export-object}\index{export\_obj() (pytan.handler.Handler method)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{pytan.handler:pytan.handler.Handler.export_obj}\pysiglinewithargsret{\code{Handler.}\bfcode{export\_obj}}{\emph{obj}, \emph{export\_format}, \emph{**kwargs}}{}
Exports a python API object to a given export format
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode
\textbf{obj} : {\hyperref[taniumpy.object_types:taniumpy.object_types.base.BaseType]{\code{taniumpy.object\_types.base.BaseType}}} or {\hyperref[taniumpy.object_types:taniumpy.object_types.result_set.ResultSet]{\code{taniumpy.object\_types.result\_set.ResultSet}}}
\begin{quote}

TaniumPy object to export
\end{quote}

\textbf{export\_format} : str
\begin{quote}

the number of servers that must equate ``completed'' in order for deploy action to be recognized as completed
\end{quote}

\textbf{header\_sort} : list of str, bool, optional
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
for \emph{export\_format} csv and \emph{obj} types {\hyperref[taniumpy.object_types:taniumpy.object_types.base.BaseType]{\code{taniumpy.object\_types.base.BaseType}}} or {\hyperref[taniumpy.object_types:taniumpy.object_types.result_set.ResultSet]{\code{taniumpy.object\_types.result\_set.ResultSet}}}

\item {} 
True: sort the headers automatically

\item {} 
False: do not sort the headers at all

\item {} 
list of str: sort the headers returned by priority based on provided list

\end{itemize}

\textbf{header\_add\_sensor} : bool, optional
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
for \emph{export\_format} csv and \emph{obj} type {\hyperref[taniumpy.object_types:taniumpy.object_types.result_set.ResultSet]{\code{taniumpy.object\_types.result\_set.ResultSet}}}

\item {} 
False: do not prefix the headers with the associated sensor name for each column

\item {} 
True: prefix the headers with the associated sensor name for each column

\end{itemize}

\textbf{header\_add\_type} : bool, optional
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
for \emph{export\_format} csv and \emph{obj} type {\hyperref[taniumpy.object_types:taniumpy.object_types.result_set.ResultSet]{\code{taniumpy.object\_types.result\_set.ResultSet}}}

\item {} 
False: do not postfix the headers with the result type for each column

\item {} 
True: postfix the headers with the result type for each column

\end{itemize}

\textbf{expand\_grouped\_columns} : bool, optional
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
for \emph{export\_format} csv and \emph{obj} type {\hyperref[taniumpy.object_types:taniumpy.object_types.result_set.ResultSet]{\code{taniumpy.object\_types.result\_set.ResultSet}}}

\item {} 
False: do not expand multiline row entries into their own rows

\item {} 
True: expand multiline row entries into their own rows

\end{itemize}

\textbf{explode\_json\_string\_values} : bool, optional
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
for \emph{export\_format} json or csv and \emph{obj} type {\hyperref[taniumpy.object_types:taniumpy.object_types.base.BaseType]{\code{taniumpy.object\_types.base.BaseType}}}

\item {} 
False: do not explode JSON strings in object attributes into their own object attributes

\item {} 
True: explode JSON strings in object attributes into their own object attributes

\end{itemize}

\textbf{minimal} : bool, optional
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
for \emph{export\_format} xml and \emph{obj} type {\hyperref[taniumpy.object_types:taniumpy.object_types.base.BaseType]{\code{taniumpy.object\_types.base.BaseType}}}

\item {} 
False: include empty attributes in XML output

\item {} 
True: do not include empty attributes in XML output

\end{itemize}

\item[{Returns}] \leavevmode
\textbf{result} : str
\begin{quote}

the contents of exporting \emph{export\_format}
\end{quote}

\end{description}\end{quote}


\strong{See also:}

\begin{description}
\item[{{\hyperref[pytan.constants:pytan.constants.EXPORT_MAPS]{\code{pytan.constants.EXPORT\_MAPS}}}}] \leavevmode
maps the type \emph{obj} to \emph{export\_format} and the optional args supported for each

\end{description}



\end{fulllineitems}

\end{itemize}

\item {}

\item {}

\end{itemize}

\textbf{minimal} : bool, optional
\begin{itemize}

\item {} 
True: do not include empty attributes in XML output

\end{itemize}

\textbf{report\_file: str, optional}
\begin{quote}

filename to save report as, will be automatically generated if not supplied
\end{quote}

\textbf{report\_dir: str, optional}
\begin{quote}

directory to save report in, if not supplied, will be extracted from \emph{report\_file}. if no directory in \emph{report\_file} or \emph{report\_file} not specified, will use current working directory.
\end{quote}

\begin{quote}

\end{quote}

\textbf{postfix: str, optional}
\begin{quote}

postfix to add to \emph{report\_file}
\end{quote}

\item[{Returns}] \leavevmode
\textbf{report\_path} : str
\begin{quote}

the full path to the file created with contents of \emph{result}
\end{quote}

\textbf{result} : str
\begin{quote}

the str of \emph{export\_format}
\end{quote}

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

\item {} 
URL of file to add to package

\item {} 
can optionally define download\_seconds by using SECONDS::URL

\item {} 
can optionally define file name by using FILENAME\textbar{}\textbar{}URL

\item {} 
can combine optionals by using SECONDS::FILENAME\textbar{}\textbar{}URL

\item {}

\end{itemize}

\end{quote}

\begin{quote}

each string must describe a filter to be used to verify the package
\end{quote}

\textbf{verify\_filter\_options} : str or list of str, optional
\begin{quote}

each string must describe an option for \emph{verify\_filters}
\end{quote}

\begin{quote}

\end{quote}

\paragraph{Handler Methods: Getting Result Data / Result Info}
\label{pytan.handler:handler-methods-getting-result-data-result-info}\index{get\_result\_data() (pytan.handler.Handler method)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{pytan.handler:pytan.handler.Handler.get_result_data}\pysiglinewithargsret{\code{Handler.}\bfcode{get\_result\_data}}{\emph{obj}, \emph{aggregate=False}, \emph{**kwargs}}{}
Get the result data for a python API object

This method issues a GetResultData command to the SOAP api for \emph{obj}. GetResultData returns the columns and rows that are currently available for \emph{obj}.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode
\textbf{obj} : {\hyperref[taniumpy.object_types:taniumpy.object_types.base.BaseType]{\code{taniumpy.object\_types.base.BaseType}}}
\begin{quote}

object to get result data for
\end{quote}

\textbf{aggregate} : bool, optional
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
False: get all the data

\item {} 
True: get just the aggregate data (row counts of matches)

\end{itemize}

\item[{Returns}] \leavevmode
\textbf{rd} : {\hyperref[taniumpy.object_types:taniumpy.object_types.result_set.ResultSet]{\code{taniumpy.object\_types.result\_set.ResultSet}}}
\begin{quote}

The return of GetResultData for \emph{obj}
\end{quote}

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{get\_result\_info() (pytan.handler.Handler method)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{pytan.handler:pytan.handler.Handler.get_result_info}\pysiglinewithargsret{\code{Handler.}\bfcode{get\_result\_info}}{\emph{obj}, \emph{**kwargs}}{}
Get the result info for a python API object

This method issues a GetResultInfo command to the SOAP api for \emph{obj}. GetResultInfo returns information about how many servers have passed the \emph{obj}, total number of servers, and so on.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode
\textbf{obj} : {\hyperref[taniumpy.object_types:taniumpy.object_types.base.BaseType]{\code{taniumpy.object\_types.base.BaseType}}}
\begin{quote}

object to get result data for
\end{quote}

\item[{Returns}] \leavevmode
\textbf{ri} : {\hyperref[taniumpy.object_types:taniumpy.object_types.result_info.ResultInfo]{\code{taniumpy.object\_types.result\_info.ResultInfo}}}
\begin{quote}

The return of GetResultData for \emph{obj}
\end{quote}

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

This contains a number of constants that drive PyTan.

\item[{Maps a given set of human strings into the various filter attributes used by the SOAP API. Also used to verify that a manually supplied filter via a definition is valid. Construct:}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}

human: a list of human strings that can be used after `\emph{, that}`. Ex: `\emph{, that} \code{contains} \code{value}`

\item {}

\item {}

\item {}

\item {}

\item[{Maps an object type from a human friendly string into various aspects:}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
single: The \code{TaniumPy} object used to find singular instances of this object type

\item {} 
multi: The \code{TaniumPy} object used to find multiple instances of this object type

\item {} 
all: The \code{TaniumPy} object used to find all instances of this object type

\item {} 
search: The list of attributes that can be used with the Tanium SOAP API for searches

\item {} 
manual: Whether or not this object type is allowed to do a manual search, that is -- allow the user to specify an attribute that is not in search, which will get ALL objects of that type then search for a match based on attribute values for EVERY key/value pair supplied

\item {} 
delete: Whether or not this object type can be deleted

\item {} 
create\_json: Whether or not this object type can be created by importing from JSON

\end{itemize}

\end{description}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{OPTION\_MAPS (in module pytan.constants)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{pytan.constants:pytan.constants.OPTION_MAPS}\pysigline{\code{pytan.constants.}\bfcode{OPTION\_MAPS}\strong{ = {[}\{`destination': `filter', `attrs': \{`ignore\_case\_flag': 1\}, `human': `ignore\_case', `valid\_type': \textless{}type `int'\textgreater{}\}, \{`destination': `filter', `attrs': \{`ignore\_case\_flag': 0\}, `human': `match\_case', `valid\_type': \textless{}type `int'\textgreater{}\}, \{`destination': `filter', `attrs': \{`all\_values\_flag': 0, `all\_times\_flag': 0\}, `human': `match\_any\_value', `valid\_type': \textless{}type `int'\textgreater{}\}, \{`destination': `filter', `attrs': \{`all\_values\_flag': 1, `all\_times\_flag': 1\}, `human': `match\_all\_values', `valid\_type': \textless{}type `int'\textgreater{}\}, \{`destination': `filter', `human\_type': `seconds', `attr': `max\_age\_seconds', `human': `max\_data\_age', `valid\_type': \textless{}type `int'\textgreater{}\}, \{`attr': `value\_type', `destination': `filter', `valid\_type': \textless{}type `str'\textgreater{}, `valid\_values': `constants.SENSOR\_TYPE\_MAP.values()', `human': `value\_type', `human\_type': `value\_type'\}, \{`destination': `group', `attrs': \{`and\_flag': 1\}, `human': `and', `valid\_type': \textless{}type `int'\textgreater{}\}, \{`destination': `group', `attrs': \{`and\_flag': 0\}, `human': `or', `valid\_type': \textless{}type `int'\textgreater{}\}{]}}}~\begin{description}
\item[{Maps a given human string into the various options for filters used by the SOAP API. Also used to verify that a manually supplied option via a definition is valid. Construct:}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
human: the human string that can be used after `\emph{opt:}`. Ex: `\emph{opt}:\code{value\_type}:\code{value}`

\item {} 
destination: the type of object this option can be applied to (filter or group)

\item {} 
attrs: the attributes and their values used by the SOAP API when building a filter with an option that matches \emph{human}

\item {} 
attr: the attribute used by the SOAP API when building a filter with an option that matches \emph{human}. \code{value} is pulled from after a \emph{:} when only attr exists for an option map, and not attrs.

\item {} 
valid\_values: if supplied, the list of valid values for this option

\item {} 
valid\_type: performs type checking on the value supplied to verify it is correct

\item {} 
human\_type: the human string for the value type if the option requires a value

\end{itemize}

\end{description}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{OPTION\_RE (in module pytan.constants)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{pytan.constants:pytan.constants.OPTION_RE}\pysigline{\code{pytan.constants.}\bfcode{OPTION\_RE}\strong{ = `,\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}s*opt:'}}
The regex that is used to find options in a string. Ex: \emph{Sensor1, that contains blah}\code{, opt:}\emph{ignore\_case}\code{, opt:}\emph{max\_data\_age:3600}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{PARAM\_DELIM (in module pytan.constants)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{pytan.constants:pytan.constants.PARAM_DELIM}\pysigline{\code{pytan.constants.}\bfcode{PARAM\_DELIM}\strong{ = `\textbar{}\textbar{}'}}
The string to surround a parameter with when passing parameters to the SOAP API for a sensor in a question. Ex: \code{\textbar{}\textbar{}}\emph{parameter\_key}\code{\textbar{}\textbar{}}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{PARAM\_KEY\_SPLIT (in module pytan.constants)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{pytan.constants:pytan.constants.PARAM_KEY_SPLIT}\pysigline{\code{pytan.constants.}\bfcode{PARAM\_KEY\_SPLIT}\strong{ = `='}}
The string that is used to split parameter key from parameter value. Ex: \emph{key1}\code{=}\emph{value1}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{PARAM\_RE (in module pytan.constants)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{pytan.constants:pytan.constants.PARAM_RE}\pysigline{\code{pytan.constants.}\bfcode{PARAM\_RE}\strong{ = `\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}\{(.*?)\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}\}'}}
The regex that is used to parse parameters from a human string. Ex: ala \{key1=value1\}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{PARAM\_SPLIT\_RE (in module pytan.constants)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{pytan.constants:pytan.constants.PARAM_SPLIT_RE}\pysigline{\code{pytan.constants.}\bfcode{PARAM\_SPLIT\_RE}\strong{ = `(?\textless{}!\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}),'}}
The regex that is used to split multiple parameters. Ex: key1=value1, key2=value2

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{Q\_OBJ\_MAP (in module pytan.constants)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{pytan.constants:pytan.constants.Q_OBJ_MAP}\pysigline{\code{pytan.constants.}\bfcode{Q\_OBJ\_MAP}\strong{ = \{`manual': \{`handler': `ask\_manual'\}, `saved': \{`handler': `ask\_saved'\}, `manual\_human': \{`handler': `ask\_manual\_human'\}\}}}
Maps a question type from a human friendly string into the handler method that supports each type

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{REQ\_KWARGS (in module pytan.constants)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{pytan.constants:pytan.constants.REQ_KWARGS}\pysigline{\code{pytan.constants.}\bfcode{REQ\_KWARGS}\strong{ = {[}'hide\_errors\_flag', `include\_answer\_times\_flag', `row\_counts\_only\_flag', `aggregate\_over\_time\_flag', `most\_recent\_flag', `include\_hashes\_flag', `hide\_no\_results\_flag', `use\_user\_context\_flag', `script\_data', `return\_lists\_flag', `return\_cdata\_flag', `pct\_done\_limit', `context\_id', `sample\_frequency', `sample\_start', `sample\_count', `suppress\_scripts', `suppress\_object\_list', `row\_start', `row\_count', `sort\_order', `filter\_string', `filter\_not\_flag', `recent\_result\_buckets', `cache\_id', `cache\_expiration', `cache\_sort\_fields', `include\_user\_details', `include\_hidden\_flag', `use\_error\_objects', `use\_json', `json\_pretty\_print'{]}}}
A list of arguments that will be pulled from any respective kwargs for most calls to {\hyperref[taniumpy.session:taniumpy.session.Session]{\code{taniumpy.session.Session}}}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{SELECTORS (in module pytan.constants)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{pytan.constants:pytan.constants.SELECTORS}\pysigline{\code{pytan.constants.}\bfcode{SELECTORS}\strong{ = {[}'id', `name', `hash'{]}}}
The search selectors that can be extracted from a string. Ex: \code{name}:\emph{Sensor1,} or \code{id}:\emph{1}, or \code{hash}:\emph{1111111}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{SENSOR\_TYPE\_MAP (in module pytan.constants)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{pytan.constants:pytan.constants.SENSOR_TYPE_MAP}\pysigline{\code{pytan.constants.}\bfcode{SENSOR\_TYPE\_MAP}\strong{ = \{0: `Hash', 1: `String', 2: `Version', 3: `NumericDecimal', 4: `BESDate', 5: `IPAddress', 6: `WMIDate', 7: `TimeDiff', 8: `DataSize', 9: `NumericInteger', 10: `VariousDate', 11: `RegexMatch', 12: `LastOperatorType'\}}}
Maps a Result type from the Tanium SOAP API from an int to a string

\end{fulllineitems}

Bases: \code{logging.Handler}

Custom \code{logging.Handler} class that sends all messages that are logging.INFO and below to STDOUT, and all messages that are logging.WARNING and above to STDERR

\subsubsection{Utility Classes: Argument Parsers for Command Line Scripts}
\label{pytan.utils:utility-classes-argument-parsers-for-command-line-scripts}\index{CustomArgFormat (class in pytan.utils)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{pytan.utils:pytan.utils.CustomArgFormat}\pysiglinewithargsret{\strong{class }\code{pytan.utils.}\bfcode{CustomArgFormat}}{\emph{prog}, \emph{indent\_increment=2}, \emph{max\_help\_position=24}, \emph{width=None}}{}
Bases: \href{http://docs.python.org/2.7/library/argparse.html\#argparse.ArgumentDefaultsHelpFormatter}{\code{argparse.ArgumentDefaultsHelpFormatter}}, \href{http://docs.python.org/2.7/library/argparse.html\#argparse.RawDescriptionHelpFormatter}{\code{argparse.RawDescriptionHelpFormatter}}

Multiple inheritance Formatter class for \href{http://docs.python.org/2.7/library/argparse.html\#argparse.ArgumentParser}{\code{argparse.ArgumentParser}}.

If a \href{http://docs.python.org/2.7/library/argparse.html\#argparse.ArgumentParser}{\code{argparse.ArgumentParser}} class uses this as it's Formatter class, it will show the defaults for each argument in the \emph{help} output

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{CustomArgParse (class in pytan.utils)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{pytan.utils:pytan.utils.CustomArgParse}\pysiglinewithargsret{\strong{class }\code{pytan.utils.}\bfcode{CustomArgParse}}{\emph{*args}, \emph{**kwargs}}{}
Bases: \href{http://docs.python.org/2.7/library/argparse.html\#argparse.ArgumentParser}{\code{argparse.ArgumentParser}}

Custom \href{http://docs.python.org/2.7/library/argparse.html\#argparse.ArgumentParser}{\code{argparse.ArgumentParser}} class which does a number of things:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Uses {\hyperref[pytan.utils:pytan.utils.CustomArgFormat]{\code{pytan.utils.CustomArgFormat}}} as it's Formatter class, if none was passed in

\item {} 
Prints help if there is an error

\item {} 
Prints the help for any subparsers that exist

\end{itemize}
\index{error() (pytan.utils.CustomArgParse method)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{pytan.utils:pytan.utils.CustomArgParse.error}\pysiglinewithargsret{\bfcode{error}}{\emph{message}}{}
\end{fulllineitems}

\index{print\_help() (pytan.utils.CustomArgParse method)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{pytan.utils:pytan.utils.CustomArgParse.print_help}\pysiglinewithargsret{\bfcode{print\_help}}{\emph{**kwargs}}{}
\end{fulllineitems}


\end{fulllineitems}



\subsubsection{Utility Functions: Logging}
\label{pytan.utils:utility-functions-logging}\index{change\_console\_format() (in module pytan.utils)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{pytan.utils:pytan.utils.change_console_format}\pysiglinewithargsret{\code{pytan.utils.}\bfcode{change\_console\_format}}{\emph{debug=False}}{}
Changes the logging format for console handler to {\hyperref[pytan.constants:pytan.constants.DEBUG_FORMAT]{\code{pytan.constants.DEBUG\_FORMAT}}} or {\hyperref[pytan.constants:pytan.constants.INFO_FORMAT]{\code{pytan.constants.INFO\_FORMAT}}}
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode
\textbf{debug} : bool, optional
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
False : set logging format for console handler to {\hyperref[pytan.constants:pytan.constants.INFO_FORMAT]{\code{pytan.constants.INFO\_FORMAT}}}

\item {} 
True :  set logging format for console handler to {\hyperref[pytan.constants:pytan.constants.DEBUG_FORMAT]{\code{pytan.constants.DEBUG\_FORMAT}}}

\end{itemize}

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

\begin{fulllineitems}

\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode

\begin{quote}

name of logging handler to remove. if name == `all' then all logging handlers are removed
\end{quote}

\end{description}\end{quote}

\index{set\_log\_levels() (in module pytan.utils)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{pytan.utils:pytan.utils.set_log_levels}\pysiglinewithargsret{\code{pytan.utils.}\bfcode{set\_log\_levels}}{\emph{loglevel=0}}{}
Enables loggers based on loglevel and {\hyperref[pytan.constants:pytan.constants.LOG_LEVEL_MAPS]{\code{pytan.constants.LOG\_LEVEL\_MAPS}}}
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode
\textbf{loglevel} : int, optional
\begin{quote}

loglevel to match against each item in {\hyperref[pytan.constants:pytan.constants.LOG_LEVEL_MAPS]{\code{pytan.constants.LOG\_LEVEL\_MAPS}}} - each item that is greater than or equal to loglevel will have the according loggers set to their respective levels identified there-in.
\end{quote}

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode

\begin{quote}

dict to sums of
\end{quote}

\textbf{keys} : list of str
\begin{quote}

list of keys to get sums of, if empty gets a sum of all keys
\end{quote}

\textbf{negate} : bool
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
only used if keys supplied

\item {} 
False : get the sums of \emph{d} that do match keys

\item {} 
True : get the sums of \emph{d} that do not match keys

\end{itemize}

\item[{Returns}] \leavevmode
\textbf{list\_len} : int
\begin{quote}

sum of lists in \emph{d} that match keys
\end{quote}

\end{description}\end{quote}

\subsubsection{Utility Functions: Argument Parsers for Command Line Scripts}
\label{pytan.utils:utility-functions-argument-parsers-for-command-line-scripts}\index{setup\_parser() (in module pytan.utils)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{pytan.utils:pytan.utils.setup_parser}\pysiglinewithargsret{\code{pytan.utils.}\bfcode{setup\_parser}}{\emph{desc}, \emph{help=False}}{}
Method to setup the base {\hyperref[pytan.utils:pytan.utils.CustomArgParse]{\code{pytan.utils.CustomArgParse}}} class for command line scripts that use {\hyperref[pytan:module-pytan]{\code{pytan}}}. This establishes the basic arguments that are needed by all such scripts, such as:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
--help

\item {} 
--username

\item {} 
--password

\item {} 
--host

\item {} 
--port

\item {} 
--loglevel

\item {} 
--debugformat (not shown in --help)

\end{itemize}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{build\_param\_objlist() (in module pytan.utils)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{pytan.utils:pytan.utils.build_param_objlist}\pysiglinewithargsret{\code{pytan.utils.}\bfcode{build\_param\_objlist}}{\emph{obj}, \emph{user\_params}, \emph{delim='`}, \emph{derive\_def=False}, \emph{empty\_ok=False}}{}
Creates a ParameterList object from user\_params
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode
\textbf{obj} : {\hyperref[taniumpy.object_types:taniumpy.object_types.base.BaseType]{\code{taniumpy.object\_types.base.BaseType}}}
\begin{quote}

TaniumPy object to verify parameters against
\end{quote}

\textbf{user\_params} : dict
\begin{quote}

dict describing key and value of user supplied params
\end{quote}

\textbf{delim} : str
\begin{quote}

str to surround key with when adding to parameter object
\end{quote}

\textbf{derive\_def} : bool, optional
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
False: Do not derive default values, and throw a {\hyperref[pytan.utils:pytan.utils.HandlerError]{\code{HandlerError}}} if user did not supply a value for a given parameter

\item {} 
True: Try to derive a default value for each parameter if user did not supply one

\end{itemize}

\textbf{empty\_ok} : bool, optional
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
False: If user did not supply a value for a given parameter, throw a {\hyperref[pytan.utils:pytan.utils.HandlerError]{\code{HandlerError}}}

\item {} 
True: If user did not supply a value for a given parameter, do not add the parameter to the ParameterList object

\end{itemize}

\item[{Returns}] \leavevmode
\textbf{param\_objlist} : {\hyperref[taniumpy.object_types:taniumpy.object_types.parameter_list.ParameterList]{\code{taniumpy.object\_types.parameter\_list.ParameterList}}}
\begin{quote}

ParameterList object with list of {\hyperref[taniumpy.object_types:taniumpy.object_types.parameter.Parameter]{\code{taniumpy.object\_types.parameter.Parameter}}} built from user\_params
\end{quote}

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

\subsection{pytan Functional Tests}
\label{pytan.functest:module-test_pytan_func}\label{pytan.functest::doc}\label{pytan.functest:pytan-functional-tests}\index{test\_pytan\_func (module)}
This contains functional tests for pytan.

These functional tests require a connection to a Tanium server in order to run.
The connection info is pulled from the SERVER\_INFO dictionary in test/API\_INFO.py.

\subsection{taniumpy.question\_asker module}
\label{taniumpy.question_asker:taniumpy-question-asker-module}\label{taniumpy.question_asker:module-taniumpy.question_asker}\label{taniumpy.question_asker::doc}\index{taniumpy.question\_asker (module)}\index{QuestionAsker (class in taniumpy.question\_asker)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{taniumpy.question_asker:taniumpy.question_asker.QuestionAsker}\pysiglinewithargsret{\strong{class }\code{taniumpy.question\_asker.}\bfcode{QuestionAsker}}{\emph{session}, \emph{question}, \emph{polling\_interval=None}, \emph{pct\_complete\_threshold=99}, \emph{timeout=300}}{}
Bases: \href{http://docs.python.org/2.7/library/functions.html\#object}{\code{object}}

A class to aid in asking a Question.

The primary function of this class is to poll for
result info for question, and fire off events:

ProgressChanged
AnswersChanged
AnswersComplete
\index{POLLING\_INTERVAL (taniumpy.question\_asker.QuestionAsker attribute)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{taniumpy.question_asker:taniumpy.question_asker.QuestionAsker.POLLING_INTERVAL}\pysigline{\bfcode{POLLING\_INTERVAL}\strong{ = 5}}
\end{fulllineitems}

\index{run() (taniumpy.question\_asker.QuestionAsker method)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{taniumpy.question_asker:taniumpy.question_asker.QuestionAsker.run}\pysiglinewithargsret{\bfcode{run}}{\emph{callbacks=\{\}}, \emph{**kwargs}}{}
Poll for question data and issue callbacks.

Callbacks should be a dict with members:
`ProgressChanged'
`AnswersChanged'
`AnswersComplete'

Each should be a function that accepts a QuestionAsker
and a percent complete.

Any callback can choose to get data from the session
by calling asker.session.getResultData(asker.question)

Polling will be stopped only when one of the callbacks
calls the stop() method or the answers are complete. Note
that callbacks can call setPercentCompleteThreshold to
change what done means on the fly

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{from\_jsonable() (taniumpy.object\_types.base.BaseType static method)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{taniumpy.object_types:taniumpy.object_types.base.BaseType.from_jsonable}\pysiglinewithargsret{\strong{static }\bfcode{from\_jsonable}}{\emph{jsonable}}{}
Inverse of to\_jsonable, with explode\_json\_string\_values=False.

This can be used to import objects from serialized JSON. This JSON should come from BaseType.to\_jsonable(explode\_json\_string\_values=False, include+type=True)
\paragraph{Examples}

\begin{Verbatim}[frame=single,commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{k}{with} \PYG{n+nb}{open}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s}{question\PYGZus{}list.json}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k}{as} \PYG{n}{fd}\PYG{p}{:}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }   \PYG{n}{questions} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{json}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{loads}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{fd}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{read}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }   \PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} is a list of serialized questions}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }   \PYG{n}{question\PYGZus{}objects} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{BaseType}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{from\PYGZus{}jsonable}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{questions}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }   \PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} will return a list of api.Question}
\end{Verbatim}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{write\_csv() (taniumpy.object\_types.base.BaseType static method)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{taniumpy.object_types:taniumpy.object_types.base.BaseType.write_csv}\pysiglinewithargsret{\strong{static }\bfcode{write\_csv}}{\emph{fd}, \emph{val}, \emph{explode\_json\_string\_values=False}, \emph{**kwargs}}{}
Write `val' to CSV. val can be a BaseType instance or a list of
BaseType

This does a two-pass, calling to\_flat\_dict for each object, then
finding the union of all headers,
then writing out the value of each column for each object
sorted by header name

explode\_json\_string\_values attempts to see if any of the str values
are parseable by json.loads, and if so treat each property as a column
value

fd is a file-like object

\end{fulllineitems}


\end{fulllineitems}

\section{xmltodict module}
\label{xmltodict:xmltodict-module}\label{xmltodict:module-xmltodict}\label{xmltodict::doc}\index{xmltodict (module)}
Makes working with XML feel like you are working with JSON
\index{parse() (in module xmltodict)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{xmltodict:xmltodict.parse}\pysiglinewithargsret{\code{xmltodict.}\bfcode{parse}}{\emph{xml\_input}, \emph{encoding=None}, \emph{expat=\textless{}module `xml.parsers.expat' from `/Library/Python/2.7/site-packages/\_xmlplus/parsers/expat.pyc'\textgreater{}}, \emph{process\_namespaces=False}, \emph{namespace\_separator=':'}, \emph{**kwargs}}{}
Parse the given XML input and convert it into a dictionary.

\emph{xml\_input} can either be a \emph{string} or a file-like object.

If \emph{xml\_attribs} is \emph{True}, element attributes are put in the dictionary
among regular child elements, using \emph{@} as a prefix to avoid collisions. If
set to \emph{False}, they are just ignored.

Simple example:

\begin{Verbatim}[frame=single,commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n+nn}{xmltodict}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{doc} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{xmltodict}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{parse}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}\PYGZdq{}\PYGZdq{}}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZlt{}a prop=}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{x}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZgt{}}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }\PYG{l+s}{  \PYGZlt{}b\PYGZgt{}1\PYGZlt{}/b\PYGZgt{}}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }\PYG{l+s}{  \PYGZlt{}b\PYGZgt{}2\PYGZlt{}/b\PYGZgt{}}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZlt{}/a\PYGZgt{}}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}\PYGZdq{}\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{doc}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s}{a}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s}{@prop}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{]}
\PYG{g+go}{u\PYGZsq{}x\PYGZsq{}}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{doc}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s}{a}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s}{b}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{]}
\PYG{g+go}{[u\PYGZsq{}1\PYGZsq{}, u\PYGZsq{}2\PYGZsq{}]}
\end{Verbatim}

If \emph{item\_depth} is \emph{0}, the function returns a dictionary for the root
element (default behavior). Otherwise, it calls \emph{item\_callback} every time
an item at the specified depth is found and returns \emph{None} in the end
(streaming mode).

The callback function receives two parameters: the \emph{path} from the document
root to the item (name-attribs pairs), and the \emph{item} (dict). If the
callback's return value is false-ish, parsing will be stopped with the
\code{ParsingInterrupted} exception.

Streaming example:

\begin{Verbatim}[frame=single,commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{k}{def} \PYG{n+nf}{handle}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{path}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{item}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }    \PYG{k}{print} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s}{path:}\PYG{l+s+si}{\PYGZpc{}s}\PYG{l+s}{ item:}\PYG{l+s+si}{\PYGZpc{}s}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}} \PYG{o}{\PYGZpc{}} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{path}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{item}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }    \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{n+nb+bp}{True}
\PYG{g+gp}{...}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{xmltodict}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{parse}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}\PYGZdq{}\PYGZdq{}}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZlt{}a prop=}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{x}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZgt{}}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }\PYG{l+s}{  \PYGZlt{}b\PYGZgt{}1\PYGZlt{}/b\PYGZgt{}}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }\PYG{l+s}{  \PYGZlt{}b\PYGZgt{}2\PYGZlt{}/b\PYGZgt{}}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZlt{}/a\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}\PYGZdq{}\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{item\PYGZus{}depth}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{item\PYGZus{}callback}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{handle}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+go}{path:[(u\PYGZsq{}a\PYGZsq{}, \PYGZob{}u\PYGZsq{}prop\PYGZsq{}: u\PYGZsq{}x\PYGZsq{}\PYGZcb{}), (u\PYGZsq{}b\PYGZsq{}, None)] item:1}
\PYG{g+go}{path:[(u\PYGZsq{}a\PYGZsq{}, \PYGZob{}u\PYGZsq{}prop\PYGZsq{}: u\PYGZsq{}x\PYGZsq{}\PYGZcb{}), (u\PYGZsq{}b\PYGZsq{}, None)] item:2}
\end{Verbatim}

The optional argument \emph{postprocessor} is a function that takes \emph{path},
\emph{key} and \emph{value} as positional arguments and returns a new \emph{(key, value)}
pair where both \emph{key} and \emph{value} may have changed. Usage example:

\begin{Verbatim}[frame=single,commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{k}{def} \PYG{n+nf}{postprocessor}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{path}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{key}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{value}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }    \PYG{k}{try}\PYG{p}{:}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }        \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{n}{key} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s}{:int}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nb}{int}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{value}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }    \PYG{k}{except} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+ne}{ValueError}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+ne}{TypeError}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }        \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{n}{key}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{value}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{xmltodict}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{parse}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZlt{}a\PYGZgt{}\PYGZlt{}b\PYGZgt{}1\PYGZlt{}/b\PYGZgt{}\PYGZlt{}b\PYGZgt{}2\PYGZlt{}/b\PYGZgt{}\PYGZlt{}b\PYGZgt{}x\PYGZlt{}/b\PYGZgt{}\PYGZlt{}/a\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }                \PYG{n}{postprocessor}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{postprocessor}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+go}{OrderedDict([(u\PYGZsq{}a\PYGZsq{}, OrderedDict([(u\PYGZsq{}b:int\PYGZsq{}, [1, 2]), (u\PYGZsq{}b\PYGZsq{}, u\PYGZsq{}x\PYGZsq{})]))])}
\end{Verbatim}

You can pass an alternate version of \emph{expat} (such as \emph{defusedexpat}) by
using the \emph{expat} parameter. E.g:

\begin{Verbatim}[frame=single,commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n+nn}{defusedexpat}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{xmltodict}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{parse}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZlt{}a\PYGZgt{}hello\PYGZlt{}/a\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{expat}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{defusedexpat}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{pyexpat}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+go}{OrderedDict([(u\PYGZsq{}a\PYGZsq{}, u\PYGZsq{}hello\PYGZsq{})])}
\end{Verbatim}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{unparse() (in module xmltodict)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{xmltodict:xmltodict.unparse}\pysiglinewithargsret{\code{xmltodict.}\bfcode{unparse}}{\emph{input\_dict}, \emph{output=None}, \emph{encoding='utf-8'}, \emph{full\_document=True}, \emph{**kwargs}}{}
Emit an XML document for the given \emph{input\_dict} (reverse of \emph{parse}).

The resulting XML document is returned as a string, but if \emph{output} (a
file-like object) is specified, it is written there instead.

Dictionary keys prefixed with \emph{attr\_prefix} (default={}`'@'\emph{) are interpreted
as XML node attributes, whereas keys equal to {}`cdata\_key}
(default={}`'\#text'{}`) are treated as character data.

The \emph{pretty} parameter (default={}`False{}`) enables pretty-printing. In this
mode, lines are terminated with \emph{`n'} and indented with \emph{`t'}, but this
can be customized with the \emph{newl} and \emph{indent} parameters.

\end{fulllineitems}



\section{ddt module}
\label{ddt:module-ddt}\label{ddt::doc}\label{ddt:ddt-module}\index{ddt (module)}\index{data() (in module ddt)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{ddt:ddt.data}\pysiglinewithargsret{\code{ddt.}\bfcode{data}}{\emph{*values}}{}
Method decorator to add to your test methods.

Should be added to methods of instances of \code{unittest.TestCase}.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{ddt() (in module ddt)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{ddt:ddt.ddt}\pysiglinewithargsret{\code{ddt.}\bfcode{ddt}}{\emph{cls}}{}
Class decorator for subclasses of \code{unittest.TestCase}.

Apply this decorator to the test case class, and then
decorate test methods with \code{@data}.

For each method decorated with \code{@data}, this will effectively create as
many methods as data items are passed as parameters to \code{@data}.

The names of the test methods follow the pattern
\code{original\_test\_name\_\{ordinal\}\_\{data\}}. \code{ordinal} is the position of the
data argument, starting with 1.

For data we use a string representation of the data value converted into a
valid python identifier.  If \code{data.\_\_name\_\_} exists, we use that instead.

For each method decorated with \code{@file\_data('test\_data.json')}, the
decorator will try to load the test\_data.json file located relative
to the python file containing the method that is decorated. It will,
for each \code{test\_name} key create as many methods in the list of values
from the \code{data} key.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{file\_data() (in module ddt)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{ddt:ddt.file_data}\pysiglinewithargsret{\code{ddt.}\bfcode{file\_data}}{\emph{value}}{}
Method decorator to add to your test methods.

Should be added to methods of instances of \code{unittest.TestCase}.

\code{value} should be a path relative to the directory of the file
containing the decorated \code{unittest.TestCase}. The file
should contain JSON encoded data, that can either be a list or a
dict.

In case of a list, each value in the list will correspond to one
test case, and the value will be concatenated to the test method
name.

In case of a dict, keys will be used as suffixes to the name of the
test case, and values will be fed as test data.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{is\_hash\_randomized() (in module ddt)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{ddt:ddt.is_hash_randomized}\pysiglinewithargsret{\code{ddt.}\bfcode{is\_hash\_randomized}}{}{}
\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mk\_test\_name() (in module ddt)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{ddt:ddt.mk_test_name}\pysiglinewithargsret{\code{ddt.}\bfcode{mk\_test\_name}}{\emph{name}, \emph{value}, \emph{index=0}}{}
Generate a new name for a test case.

It will take the original test name and append an ordinal index and a
string representation of the value, and convert the result into a valid
python identifier by replacing extraneous characters with \code{\_}.

If hash randomization is enabled (a feature available since 2.7.3/3.2.3
and enabled by default since 3.3) and a ``non-trivial'' value is passed
this will omit the name argument by default. Set \emph{PYTHONHASHSEED}
to a fixed value before running tests in these cases to get the
names back consistently or use the \emph{\_\_name\_\_} attribute on data values.

A ``trivial'' value is a plain scalar, or a tuple or list consisting
only of trivial values.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{unpack() (in module ddt)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{ddt:ddt.unpack}\pysiglinewithargsret{\code{ddt.}\bfcode{unpack}}{\emph{func}}{}
Method decorator to add unpack feature.

\end{fulllineitems}
